ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Knowledge/themes: the representation of women/witches in Hispanic culture, the effect of environmental changes/deforestation on Amazonian indigenous tribes, and the struggles faced by migrants.
Skills: greatly improved writing skills in Spanish, improved pronunciation
Insights: a greater understanding of the above facets of Hispanic/Latino culture
I learned a lot about different cultures (particularly indigenous cultures in Latin America), and improved my written and spoken Spanish abilities considerably.
I improved my skills in Spanish writing, grammar, and speaking
I polished my Spanish grammar skills and learned a lot about the diversity of the Spanish-speaking world.
I learned a bit of Spanish grammar and got better at Spanish writing
I learned how to synthesize information well in Spanish while also focusing on communicating my ideas in writing and in class.
I learned more about Spanish culture and expanded my knowledge on grammar conventions.
I developed an understanding of spanish culture and literature
I thoroughly developed my skills in reading, writing, speaking, and listening to Spanish.
Immigration, environment, and gender studies in Spanish
Really great for learning to speak Spanish; the pair conversations help a lot. Useful learning of the subjunctive and various indigenous cultures

I improved my listening and reading skills quite a bit! I am now fine reading a 300pg memoir in Spanish to keep up my skills over the summer, and prior to taking the Span130, Span140 sequence (both with Diaz) I had never read more than a page from practice books.
I learned how to write well in Spanish. I learned about Spanish music.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: good writing skills, grading breakdown percentages were very fair, feedback given on all assignments
Weaknesses: content units were rather specific, and impractical to someone trying to learn conversational/everyday Spanish. Little perceived unity across all sections of the course.
I like the level of Spanish expected from us, that we had to write on advanced topics with a variety of grammar structures. I feel our asynchronous days were too much work and not as helpful.
None
The course does an excellent job of exposing students to Spanish in various mediums but could use more grammatical instruction.
It is incredibly confusing the expectations are impossible to underestand and the curriculum is all over the place
I felt that the homework/project/exam instructions on canvas were not always aligned with what Dr. Diaz wanted.

I think the overall course is very strong, but one of the weaknesses is that the directions for assignments are not all always clear. Extra clarification in the instructions could go a long way to improve the course
Professor Diaz was always incredibly energetic which made the course engaging and exciting.
Good assignments and time to work together with peers
Strong teacher engagement

Strengths
- Lots of practice in each of: reading, writing, speaking, and listening
- Engaging projects and deep topics that make learning more interesting
- Hybrid day allowed for flexibility
Weaknesses
- Classes every day is a lot. Though may be necessary for effective language learning.

I think that I learned about very niche topics and have very few concrete language skills that can be applied in the "real world." I wish we learned about more common topics like sports, education systems, food, etc.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For those interested in actually improving their fluency in Spanish, yes. If not, no.
Yes! The professor was very engaged with the students and gave us great feedback. We had so many chances to practice our skills
I would recommend this course to a student who wants to improve upon the basic Spanish skills they learned in lower-level courses.
If you absolutely have to take it yeah otherwise definitely not.
I would recommend this class to others because I learned a lot and it contributed significantly to my comprehension and fluency.
Yes, especially with Sebastin
Absolutely, especially with Seor Daz
Yes I would, Diaz is a great professor, and I learned a lot through this course.
I loved my teacher so much. The course itself was not my favorite, mostly because I thought the topics were obscure or not applicable to general communication.
